content: In Joyal's notes on quasicategories he discusses a factorization system on small 1-categories (Cat is considered as a 1-category here) with left class "iterated strict localizations" and right class conservative functors. Here a strict localization is a functor isomorphic to something of the form C→C[W−1]\mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}]C→C[W−1] for a small category C\mathcal{C}C and set of maps WWW in C\mathcal{C}C and an iterated strict localization is a transfinite composite of these. He says we need to talk about iterated localizations because if we have a functor F:C→DF : \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D}F:C→D and set W={f∣F(f) is an isomorphism}W = \{ f \mid F(f) \text{ is an isomorphism} \}W={f∣F(f) is an isomorphism}, giving a factorization of FFF into a strict localization P:C→C[W−1]P : \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}]P:C→C[W−1] followed by a functor G:C[W−1]→DG : \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}] \to \mathcal{D}G:C[W−1]→D, the resulting GGG might not be conservative. So even after inverting everything inverted by FFF we may still need to invert yet more maps V⊆C[W−1]\mathcal{V} \subseteq \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}]V⊆C[W−1], those inverted by GGG. And P−1(V)=WP^{-1}(\mathcal{V}) = \mathcal{W}P−1(V)=W, so these are genuinely new things created in the localization. What's an example of a functor FFF where this occurs? An example where we need to iterate transfinitely many times would be appreciated

because f1∘f2−1f_1 \circ f_2^{-1}f1​∘f2−1​ needs to wait for f2−1∈C[W−1]f_2^{-1} \in \mathcal{C}[W^{-1}]f2−1​∈C[W−1] to be computed?

Then W=F−1(Iso)W = F^{-1}(\mathrm{Iso})W=F−1(Iso) contains only ggg (and identities), so C[W−1]C[W^{-1}]C[W−1] inverts only ggg. The reason I was thinking about this is I wanted to know whether any limit is the limit of a conservative functor. But my original framing of the question was wrong, since I thought you could factor through the localization and get something conservative. That said, is the following true?

Let F:J→CF : \mathcal{J} \to \mathcal{C}F:J→C be a functor which has a limit. Factor F=G∘pF = G\circ pF=G∘p with GGG conservative and ppp an iterated strict localization. Is it true that GGG has a limit and lim⁡G→lim⁡F\lim G \to \lim FlimG→limF is an isomorphism?

If ppp is a localization I think we can prove this by reducing to C=Set\mathcal{C} = \mathsf{Set}C=Set with the yoneda embedding and arguing explicitly there (identifying the limits with subsets of a product and showing they're equal by looking at equations). Iterating this finitely many times is fine, but I'm not sure how to extend transfinitely (and my proof for the one step case is pretty sketchy). Does anyone have a reference for this? Or maybe a slick proof using factorization systems?

Interesting question! Here's an attempt at a slick proof using factorization systems. As you say, suppose F:J→CF:J\to CF:J→C has a limit, call it ℓ\ellℓ, and that F=GPF = GPF=GP with PPP left orthogonal to all conservative functors. (In fact I don't think we need that GGG is conservative.) Then we know that the map Cone(x,F)→C(x,ℓ)\mathrm{Cone}(x,F) \to C(x,\ell)Cone(x,F)→C(x,ℓ) is an isomorphism, and we want to show that the map Cone(x,G)→C(x,ℓ)\mathrm{Cone}(x,G) \to C(x,\ell)Cone(x,G)→C(x,ℓ) is an isomorphism. By 3-for-2, it suffices to show that the map Cone(x,G)→Cone(x,F)\mathrm{Cone}(x,G) \to \mathrm{Cone}(x,F)Cone(x,G)→Cone(x,F) is an isomorphism, and now we don't need any more to mention the fact that FFF has a limit. So we can try to prove that for all functors F:J→CF:J\to CF:J→C with a factorization F=GPF = GPF=GP where PPP is left orthogonal to conservative functors, we have that the map Cone(x,G)→Cone(x,F)\mathrm{Cone}(x,G) \to \mathrm{Cone}(x,F)Cone(x,G)→Cone(x,F) is an isomorphism.

Next observe that to give a functor F:J→CF:J\to CF:J→C and a cone over it with vertex xxx is equivalent to giving a functor F′:J→x/CF' : J \to x/CF′:J→x/C to the co-slice under xxx. And therefore, given F:J→CF:J\to CF:J→C, to give a cone over it with vertex xxx is to give a lifting of FFF along the projection Ux:x/C→CU_x : x/C \to CUx​:x/C→C. But UxU_xUx​ is conservative! Thus, given FFF and a cone over it, we have a commutative square G∘P=Ux∘F′G \circ P = U_x \circ F'G∘P=Ux​∘F′, where UxU_xUx​ is conservative and PPP is left orthogonal to conservative functors. Therefore, there is a unique lifting, mapping the codomain of PPP to x/Cx/Cx/C, i.e. a unique extension of our given cone over FFF to a cone over GGG with vertex xxx. This is what we wanted.
And it makes sense that we wouldn't need G to be conservative, since my original argument (where we just localize once) was in that situation

I almost have an easier argument: (iterated strict) localizations are both initial and final, because discrete fibrations and opfibrations are conservative. So the loc-cons factorization system is comparable to the comprehensive ones in the order on factorization systems. Therefore as long as you know GGG has a limit it will be the same as the limit of G∘p.G\circ p.G∘p. Maybe you need Mike’s argument in the case where you don’t know a priori that GGG has a limit at all, though.
I’ve just never thought about the question of whether it’s possible to have an initial functor fff such that some D∘fD\circ fD∘f has a limit while DDD does not!

I think we can use the yoneda embedding to assume the limit is taken in a presheaf category, then argue that the limits of D and D°f are the same by initiality so D has a representable limit in the presheaf category and thus a limit in the original category
Your argument also made me realize that in the problem I'm working on I might as well replace my functor with a discrete opfibration instead of just a conservative functor
Although I'm less certain the things I want to be preserved are preserved

Thanks Kevin! Since my Ux:x/C→CU_x : x/C\to CUx​:x/C→C is also a discrete opfibration, my argument can also be regarded as a re-proof of the fact that functors that are left orthogonal to discrete opfibrations are final.
Discrete opfibrations are pretty great, you should use them if you can.

Well the problem I'm thinking about is what limits exist in the augmented simplex category. I conjectured that if a diagram with inhabited indexing category has a limit then some projection from the limit to an object in the diagram must be injective. I was able to wlog to the case where the projections are all surjective, the functor defining the diagram is conservative, and the diagram category is skeletal (this implies the domain category is both direct and inverse, or "finite length"). To get this reduction to go through I used the fact that iterated strict localizations are the identity on objects, so the objects in the diagram & the projections to them stay the same (except when throwing away isomorphic copies when we take skeleta). But if we use the initial/discrete opfibration factorization system it's not so clear to me how to translate information back to the original diagram
